content.title: Introduction
content.sortContent:
What is CSS?
Why Use CSS?

content.title: Syntax
content.sortContent: A CSS rule set consists of a selector and a declaration block:

content.title: Selectors
content.sortContent:
CSS selectors allow you to select and manipulate HTML elements.
CSS selectors are used to 'find' (or select) HTML elements based on their id, class, type, attribute, and more.

content.title: How To
content.sortContent: When a browser reads a style sheet, it will format the document according to the information in the style sheet.

content.title: Backgrounds
content.sortContent:
CSS background properties are used to define the background effects of an element.
CSS properties used for background effects:
  • background-color
  • background-image
  • background-repeat
  • background-attachment
  • background-position

content.title: Text
content.sortContent: Text can style with some of the text formatting properties. The heading uses the text-align, text-transform, and color properties. The paragraph is indented, aligned, and the space between characters is specified. The underline is removed from the 'Try it yourself' link.

content.title: Fonts
content.sortContent: CSS font properties define the font family, boldness, size, and the style of a text.

content.title: Links
content.sortContent: Links can be styled in different ways.

content.title: Lists
content.sortContent:
The CSS list properties allow you to:
  • Set different list item markers for ordered lists
  • Set different list item markers for unordered lists
  • Set an image as the list item marker

content.title: Tables
content.sortContent: The look of an HTML table can be greatly improved with CSS.

content.title: Box Model
Border
content.sortContent:
CSS Border Properties

The CSS border properties allow you to specify the style, size, and color of an element's border.

content.title: Outline
Margin
content.sortContent: The CSS margin properties define the space around elements.

content.title: Padding
content.sortContent: The CSS padding properties define the space between the element border and the element content.

content.title: Dimension
content.sortContent: The CSS dimension properties allow you to control the height and width of an element.

content.title: Display
content.sortContent: The display property is the most important CSS property for controlling layout.

content.title: Max-width
content.sortContent: Max-width will improve the browser's handling of small windows. This is important when making a site usable on small devices

content.title: Position
content.sortContent: The position property specifies the type of positioning method used for an element (static, relative, fixed or absolute).

content.title: Float
content.sortContent:
The float property specifies whether or not an element should float.
The clear property is used to control the behavior of floating elements.

content.title: Inline-block
content.sortContent: inline-block elements are like inline elements but they can have a width and height.

content.title: Align
content.sortContent: In CSS, several properties can be used to align elements horizontally.

content.title: Combinators
content.sortContent:
A CSS selector can contain more than one simple selector. Between the simple selectors, we can include a combinator.
There are four different combinators in CSS3:
  • descendant selector
  • child selector
  • adjacent sibling selector
  • general sibling selector

content.title: Pseudo-class
content.sortContent:
A pseudo-class is used to define a special state of an element.
For example, it can be used to:
  • Style an element when a user mouses over it
  • Style visited and unvisited links differently

content.title: Pseudo-element
content.sortContent: A CSS pseudo-element is used to style specified parts of an element.li>Style the first letter, or line, of an elementli>Insert content before, or after, the content of an element

content.title: Navigation Bar
content.sortContent:
Having easy-to-use navigation is important for any web site.
With CSS you can transform boring HTML menus into good-looking navigation bars.

content.title: Image Gallery
content.sortContent: CSS can be used to create an image gallery.

content.title: Image Opacity
content.sortContent:
Creating transparent images with CSS is easy.
The CSS opacity property is a part of the CSS3 recommendation.

content.title: Image Sprites
content.sortContent:
An image sprite is a collection of images put into a single image.
A web page with many images can take a long time to load and generates multiple server requests.
Using image sprites will reduce the number of server requests and save bandwidth.

content.title: Media Types
content.sortContent:
Some CSS properties are designed for a specific type of media. For example the voice-family property is designed for aural user agents.
Some other CSS properties can be used for different media types. For example, the font-size property can be used for both screen and print media, but perhaps with different values. A document usually needs a larger font-size on a screen than on paper, and sans-serif fonts are easier to read on the screen, while serif fonts are easier to read on paper.

content.title: Attr Selectors
content.sortContent: The [attribute] selector is used to select elements with a specified attribute.
